metadata.case_name: Prof. Ram Singh & Ors. v. State

facts.text: Petitioners are President, Vice-President and Secretary of the Hindu Mahasabha of the Delhi State.

Petitioners arrested on 22nd August, 1950, by order of the District Magistrate, Delhi, under sub-section (2) read with clause (a) sub-clause (i) of sub-section (1) of section 3 of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950.
Detention order by Rameshwar Dayal, District Magistrate, Delhi, satisfied necessary for maintenance of public order in Delhi.

Grounds of detention communicated under section 7: speeches generally in the past and particularly on August 1950 (specific dates for each: 13th and 15th for Prof. Ram Singh, 15th for Bal Raj Khanna, 13th for Ram Nath Kalia) at public meetings in Delhi such as to excite disaffection between Hindus and Muslims and prejudice maintenance of public order.
Petitioners applied to High Court at Simla under article 226, petitions dismissed by Khosla and Falshaw JJ.
District Magistrate filed affidavit stating satisfaction from materials that detention necessary to prevent prejudicial acts to public order, denying mala fides.

legal_issues.text: Whether detention under section 3 of Preventive Detention Act valid despite abridging freedom of speech under article 19(1)(a), in light of Romesh Thapar and Brij Bhushan cases, or governed solely by articles 21 and 22 as per A.K. Gopalan.
Whether grounds of detention too vague and indefinite, failing to comply with article 22(5), requiring gist or offending passages of speeches.
Whether orders invalid for not specifying period of detention.
Whether detention mala fide to stifle political opposition.

petitioner_arguments.text: Provisions of Act cannot be used to prevent speeches prejudicial to public order as maintenance of public order not authorised restriction on freedom of speech under article 19(2), per Romesh Thapar and Brij Bhushan.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Articles 19(1)(a), 19(2); Romesh Thapar v. State of Madras (1950 SCR 594); Brij Bhushan v. State of Delhi (1950 SCR 605)

petitioner_arguments.text: Grounds vague, do not specify offending passages or gist of speeches, insufficient for effective representation under article 22(5), per State of Bombay v. Atma Ram.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 22(5); State of Bombay v. Atma Ram Sridhar Vaidya (1951 SCR 167)

petitioner_arguments.text: Orders do not specify period of detention, making them indefinite.
Detention mala fide to stifle political opposition of Hindu Mahasabha against Congress policies.

respondent_arguments.text: Detention valid under section 3 for maintenance of public order, grounds sufficient as time, place and general effect stated; no need for specific passages.
No mala fides; satisfaction based on materials from experienced investigators.

court_reasoning.text: Detention governed by A.K. Gopalan; article 19 not applicable to personal liberty deprivation under articles 21/22; no conflict with Romesh Thapar etc. which concern direct restrictions on speech, not detention.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Personal liberty distinct from article 19 freedoms; detention prevents prejudicial acts without testing under article 19.

court_reasoning.text: Grounds not vague; time, place, general nature and effect specified sufficient for representation; no need for passages as not prosecution; distinguishes secret speeches.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Communication enables representation; requiring passages would undermine Act in legitimate cases.

court_reasoning.text: Period not needed as section 12 prescribes maximum one year.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Per Ujager Singh v. State of Punjab.

court_reasoning.text: No proof of mala fides; affidavit denies, petitioners failed burden.
Dissent (Mahajan/Bose): Grounds insufficient without gist/substance of speeches for effective representation under article 22(5); public speeches, no privilege claimed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Detenu cannot rebut inference without knowing premises; analogy to criminal charges under IPC 153A.

holdings.text: Preventive detention under section 3 valid despite impact on article 19(1)(a); governed by articles 21/22 per Gopalan.
Grounds sufficient; no need for specific passages/gist in these circumstances.
No need to specify detention period.

precedents_cited.case_name: A.K. Gopalan v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Section 3 of Act constitutional; Art 19 not applicable to detention, only Arts 21/22.

precedents_cited.case_name: Romesh Thapar v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Restrictions on speech under Art 19(2) limited to security of State, not public order.

precedents_cited.case_name: Brij Bhushan v. State of Delhi
State of Bombay v. Atma Ram Sridhar Vaidya
precedents_cited.relevance: Grounds must enable representation; vagueness justiciable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ujager Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: No need to specify period; s.12 provides maximum.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jagjit Singh v. State of Punjab

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Personal liberty, freedom of speech, detention procedures, writs.

statutes_cited.name: Preventive Detention Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Detention orders, communication of grounds, maximum period.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Analogy for speeches exciting disaffection; charge requirements.

outcome.summary: Petitions under article 32 dismissed by majority (Patanjali Sastri J.); dissents by Mahajan J. and Bose J. holding grounds vague and ordering release. Detention upheld as valid.

key_quotes.text: "Although personal liberty has a content sufficiently comprehensive to include the freedoms enumerated in article 19(1), ... the Constitution has treated these civil liberties as distinct fundamental rights."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes Art 19 from detention under Arts 21/22.

key_quotes.text: "If on reading the ground furnished it is capable of being intelligently understood and is sufficiently definite to furnish materials to enable the detained person to make a representation against the order of detention, it cannot be called vague."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test for vagueness from Atma Ram.

key_quotes.text: "Without knowing the substance of the offending passages in the speeches from which the inference has been drawn by the District Magistrate it is possible to prove that this inference is not justified."
key_quotes.speaker: Mahajan J.
key_quotes.significance: Dissent on need for gist of speeches.

key_quotes.text: "It is the duty of this Court ... to guard and defend these rights jealously."
key_quotes.speaker: Bose J.
